title: Semano: Semantic Annotation Framework for NaturalLanguage Resources

author: Nadeschda Nikitina, Department of Computer Science, University of Oxford

segmentation: Hi so I'm not just a nickatina from the University of Oxford and I'm presenting a joint work with David Berry about the software called Simmoneau.
See Mono is a framework for annotating natural language texts with concepts and relations from ontologies.
So the aim of Simmoneau is to help you achieve something like this.
So here we have a natural language text.
Well, to be more precise, it is a publication from the domain of nanotechnology.
And each of this colored highlighted areas corresponds to an annotation produced by Simmoneau.
So each of these annotations represents an occurrence of a concept or relation from the ontology.
Simone is based on the mechanism of jape transducers that is part of the gate framework.
How many of you have heard of jape transducers before?
So if you have heard and.
OK, not so many.
So J trust users basically help you to develop this kind of annotation applications.
By providing some framework and you can write simple rules and then give it to Jeff Transducer and it will run this rules and generate some annotations for you.
And this japansk use us.
They work on a set of annotations.
So assume that you have.
Set of gate applications in this applications generate different kinds of annotations for you.
So for example, you have a.
Sentence later.
Tokenizer, part of speech tagger.
All of this applications generate some annotations for you with different characteristics and now what you can do is you can use all of these different characteristics.
Just specify rules to create some new annotations.
So for example, if you have an annotation with the string value, materials and part of speech noun.
Then in your rule, you can say that.
You would like to create a new annotation corresponding to concept occurrence for the concept material for example.
So I have worked with a lot of this rule specifications during my PhD in Kizoa and well, it is a great mechanism and great framework.
But we have realized that there are quite a few things that can be done better and one.
Such limitation or one core problem when working with this mechanism of jape transducers is a large amount of redundancy in the rule base.
So if you keep on specifying this jape rules at some point, you realize that you have a large number of rules that are very similar to each other.
So just to give you an impression of how much redundancy we're talking about here, isn't it?
Example of such jape rule, and it is not necessary for you to understand all of the technical details.
But if you look at this.
This part here you see that there are 40 more lines of Java code.
That come with it, so it's in total around 50 lines of code.
And in this non rulebase that we have developed.
There were 18 rule definitions that look almost the same apart from the values in blue, so the only varying components of this rule definitions are the blue values.
So as you can imagine, if you have a large number of so large amount of redundancy in the rule based like this, then it makes it extremely difficult to maintain this full base.
And here too, to approach this problem, we can borrow some some concepts from software engineering.
So for example.

But we have this notion of procedures where you make your code more generic by introducing some parameters, and then if you have a concrete values for these parameters, you just run this generic procedure that is applicable for different values of this parameters.
And this is exactly what we do here.
So.
We
Instead of having this 18 Jeep rules that look exactly the same, we have this generic template we call this templates J plates.
We have these gaps here that need to be filled in with concrete values.
Um?
What do you do with this J plates?
You instantiate them to get the concrete J Pro and this instantiation looks pretty much like a procedure hold, so you have a.
Well, you have a rule name and then you call that a plate and supply the argument values to it.
So the list of arguments of course is specific to the particular J plate that you're using.
So in this case we were supplying the YRI of dermatology.
We're supplying a name of a relation and we're supplying to concepts from Don Teologi, but what you could do as well as you could supply some, for example some string values or.
Are some particular characteristics of the annotation, so you could say that something should be a noun.
Um?
And then you get a concrete shape.
Roll once you start the actual annotation, so as a result of this.
Additional layer of abstraction.
Our non rule based became significantly smaller.
And more important, it also became notably easier to update because now we have this generic part exactly in one place.
To give you an impression.
Of both of the effect of this additional layer abstraction, the most commonly used J plate was used around 16,000 times.
In the in the entire rulebase.
And one minute OK. Additional advantage of this succinct representation of rules is that now you can actually edit this rules and create some new rules using a visual tool.
So, for example, you could just click on on this editing button.

So there is this edit button and then you get the list of parameters that you need to change or need to fill out to create a new rule and this makes it much easier of course to persuade domain experts to help you develop such a global basis.
OK, so let me just quickly summarize the features of Simmoneau so we.
This modularity related features, including the core J plus mechanism and we have two extensions for this mechanism.

So for example, we allow you to use a variable number of arguments, which makes it applicable to in more situations, and we also introduced the notion of abstract Jay Payton sensations, where you can supply just a subset of arguments and then you end up with something that you can use as a J plate.
But with a shorter list of arguments.
And then we have features for user convenience.
So for example we have generic J plates that help you to get started with the development of such a rule based.
And we have also generic tool for generating an initialism under rule base from an ontology.
So this this initial rule based of course won't give you high precision and recall, it is well, it is meant to help you to get started and give you some ideas and also.
I will point you towards ideas for concrete syntactic patterns for different relations, for example.
Samantha also integrates a selection of reasons that can be used in annotation process and last but not least, it has different user interfaces.
So for example, and user interface for editing, rule basis and user interface for exploring annotated texts.
That's it.
Thanks investment so.
